key_title: Key to the species of Gahnia

breadcrumbs.key_title: Key to the main groups of plants in Victoria
Key to the families of Monocotyledons
Key to the genera of Cyperaceae

source.author: Wilson, K.L.
source.title: Cyperaceae
source.in_title: Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons
source.citation: Modified from: Wilson, K.L. (1994). Cyperaceae. In: Walsh, N.G.; Entwisle, T.J. (eds), Flora of Victoria. Vol. 2. Ferns and Allied Plants, Conifers and Monocotyledons. Inkata Press, Melbourne.

leads.lead_text: Ligule chartaceous or membranous, narrow, glabrous or fimbriate on upper margin (hairs 0.1 mm long or less)
Ligule long-ciliate or woolly
Lowest 7–12 glumes of spikelet much shorter than upper glumes (less than one-third length of spikelet), so that nut-bearing spikelet is pyriform or clavate
Glumes similar in length or 1–2 lowest or uppermost shorter than the rest;nut-bearing spikelet not pyriform or clavate
Stamen filaments to 8 mm long; nut 2.5–3.0 mm long, orange to red, with apex obtuse to broad-acute, umbonate
Stamen filaments to 20 mm long; nut 3.0–4.5 mm long, red-brown to dark brown, with apex acute
Mature spikelets yellow-brown or red-brown
Mature spikelets dark grey-brown to black
Culms to 45 cm high, 1–2 mm diam.; spikelets 2-flowered, with 6–9 glumes; leaves about as long as culms
Culms to 125 cm high, 2–5 mm diam.; spikelets 1-flowered (rarely 2-flowered in G. trifida), with 2–6 glumes; leaves longer than culms, often longer than inflorescences
Involucral bracts leaf-like, longer than inflorescence; culms 4–5 mm diam.; anthers 0.9–1.3 mm long (including apical appendage 0.2–0.3 mm long); chiefly rainforest areas of the far east

Involucral bracts not leaf-like, shorter than inflorescence; culms 2–4 mm diam.; anthers 1.8–2.3 mm long (including apical appendage 0.4–0.5 mm long); mostly near-coastal, usually in saline or brackish swamps, often fringing saltmarsh

Nut ± linear to very narrow-ovoid, triquetrous, 5.0–6.0 mm long, 1.0–1.5 mm diam., with surface very finely granulate, glistening; spikelets with 2–3 glumes; leaves and leafy bracts smooth to finely scabrous

Nut narrow-obovoid to narrow-ellipsoid, trigonous, 2.0–2.6 mm long, 0.8- 1.0 mm diam., with surface smooth and reticulate, shining; spikelets with 3–6 glumes; leaves and leafy bracts coarsely scabrous
Nut red to orange (yellowish when immature)
Nut straw-coloured to dark brown, grey or black
Nut 2.5–4.0 mm long; anthers 2.7–3.2 mm long (including apical appendage 0.3–0.5 mm long); culms 5–12 mm diam., hollow; forming big tussocks to 3 m high; widespread in lowlands, rare in montane areas
Nut 4.0–4.5 mm long; anthers 1.9–2.5 mm long (including appendage c. 0.2 mm long); culms 3–5 mm diam., solid; forming small tussocks to 125 cm high; montane swamps in east and rare
Culms to 45 cm high, 1–2 mm diam.; spikelets with all glumes subequal; basal leaves numerous; dry, often rocky areas
Culms to 70 cm high, 2.5–5 mm diam.; spikelets with uppermost 2–3 glumes much shorter than the lower 2–4; basal leaves rather few; chiefly inhabiting poorly drained sites
Leaf apex uncinate; base of plant dull; Grampians only
Leaf apex straight, pungent; base of plant ± shining; mallee areas

Leaves scabrous; glumes very long-mucronate, ± densely woolly on margins; stamens 4–7 (The 1964 specimen from near Dadwells Bridge is considered to have been mislabelled, and therefore the species is excluded from the Victorian flora.)
Leaves ± smooth; glumes acuminate to long-acute, glabrous; stamens 3
